title: Here's some math for all of you people saying that Mana-pools and Meditation will be insanely high:
body:
Average Mana per Mage-Champions at level 18 is 1000--1300, with a few here and there that break 1400 and then Kassadin and Janna sitting at the top with 1500.

{{item:3027}} Will only give 400 Mana now after 10 minutes of stacking.
{{item:3040}} Gives 1000 at max stacks, so 7-10 minutes of stacking based on the champion using it.
{{item:3165}} Will give 400 the moment you upgrade it.

So all together the average Mage champion who will be buying these items just to afford to use their spells will reach a Mana-pool of around 2800--3100 at max-level with 3 full items, so exactly the same as right now since ROA gives us 800 Mana after 10 minutes.

So for those that are saying that Meditation is going to be buffed significantly by this change: If a Mage runs completely dry and maxes out the power of Meditation they'll reach up to a bonus of 42--46.5 Mana per five seconds at max-level with 3 full items, and that bonus will steadily decrease with every % of Mana the Mage gets back. And guess what? With no other Mana-Regen stats in your entire build that equals dick all in terms of Mana.

So I'll say it again: once a Mage inevitably runs out of Mana, since the only way for them to push and clear waves is to use their spells, they're screwed because they have no way to get it back other than tanking enemy damage.

Well, the value is partly that Ziggs can't stall a game for 30 minutes. I like that. And Riot has stated over and over, before this update and specifically regarding this update, that mage waveclear has been a problem for the game. A problem they intend to fix. 

Honestly, shutting down ability spam is a great way to do it. I do understand the lash-back, but I think people are being unfair in not giving it a chance before casting the vote. It's always good to be skeptical of changes, but this isn't skepticism. It's just negative echo-chamber nonsense. 

I'm not trying to argue it's the greatest thing since sliced bread. I just want people to give it a chance, hence the reason for my more nebulous comments.

I personally prefer 5v5 teamfights over every other kind of team strategy. Every other strategy I find boring to watch, and boring to play with/against unless I am the person being successful. I don't enjoy winning with split-push unless I am the person that did it, and I hate losing to split-push. The same applies to pick/poke comps. The only time I am satisfied with a loss, or at least the time I am the least annoyed by it, is when it was in a full om 5v5 teamfight. Only then do I feel that the better team actually won, and not just the one that cheesed harder. 

Mages being unable to wave clear indefinitely, undercuts the need to force a teamfight against them and therefor allows for split-push and pick strategies to succeed.

We don't want to be the one person who has to go back, especially when our counterparts, AD casters don't suffer those issues, deal plenty of damage, and also take objectives more easily.

What could happen is mages lose out on the 100% uptime that everyone else has.  But then in trade for reliability, more power should be allocated.  This is one possible balance route.
